name: Guan Yu
subtitle: God of War, Righteousness, and Loyalty
description: Guan Yu is one of China's most revered deities, a historical general from the Three Kingdoms period (220-280 CE) who was deified for his unwavering loyalty, righteousness, and martial prowess. Worshipped by warriors, police, merchants, and gangsters alike, he represents the ideal of honorable conduct and brotherhood - a mortal who earned godhood through exemplary virtue.
titles: Emperor Guan the Great (关圣大帝)
symbols: Green Dragon Crescent Blade (青龙偃月刀)

historicalFigure.role: General under Liu Bei during the late Han dynasty and Three Kingdoms period
historicalFigure.significance: His life exemplified the virtues of loyalty, righteousness, and bravery

physicalDescription.face: Famous bright red face symbolizing loyalty, bravery, and uprightness
physicalDescription.beard: Magnificent long black beard, often called the 'Beautiful Beard Lord' (美髯公)
physicalDescription.height: Described as nine chi (over 2 meters) tall in Romance of the Three Kingdoms

sacredWeapons.name: Green Dragon Crescent Blade (青龙偃月刀)
sacredWeapons.description: Legendary guandao weighing 82 jin (about 50 kg), named for the dragon engraved on its blade

sacredWeapons.name: Red Hare (赤兔马)
sacredWeapons.description: Legendary horse, said to be the finest in the land, given to him by Cao Cao

mythology_content.overview: Guan Yu's mythology is unique in Chinese religion: a fully historical figure whose deification occurred gradually over centuries, driven by imperial decree, popular veneration, and literary legend.

deificationProcess.event: First temples built in his honor
Given title of Duke, worship formalized
Full imperial sacrifices ordered; worship spread globally with Chinese diaspora

keyMyths.title: The Oath of the Peach Garden
keyMyths.description: Guan Yu, Liu Bei, and Zhang Fei swore eternal brotherhood in a peach garden, pledging to 'live together and die together.' This oath became the model for all sworn brotherhoods in Chinese culture.

keyMyths.title: Riding Alone for Thousands of Miles
keyMyths.description: When temporarily separated from Liu Bei, Guan Yu passed through five gates and killed six generals of Cao Cao's forces to reunite with his sworn brother. This journey demonstrated his absolute loyalty.

keyMyths.title: Releasing Cao Cao at Huarong Pass
keyMyths.description: Despite orders to kill the fleeing Cao Cao, Guan Yu released him due to Cao Cao's earlier kindness to him. This act showed that his sense of righteousness transcended military duty.

keyMyths.title: Reading Spring and Autumn Annals
keyMyths.description: Guan Yu was famed for reading Confucius's Spring and Autumn Annals while on military watch, symbolizing his combination of martial prowess and scholarly virtue.

keyMyths.title: Surgery While Playing Chess
keyMyths.description: When poisoned by an arrow, Guan Yu calmly played chess while the physician Hua Tuo scraped the poison from his bone - demonstrating superhuman courage and composure.

Anyone seeking protection, justice, or success
